content.definition:
n. 1. Promptness in responding.
The seller of the classic car accepted my dad’s first offer with such alacrity that he wished he had offered less.
2. Eagerness.
At the beginning of recess, the children ran to the playground with alacrity.

n. 1. A large group of people or things.
The ship’s cabin contained an array of charts and maps.
2. An orderly arrangement or display.
The array of delectable desserts tempted the diners.
v. 1. To place in order.
The marching band was arrayed at the entrance to the stadium for the Thanksgiving game.
2. To dress up.
The guests had arrayed themselves in elaborate attire for the elegant ball.

v. To draw a conclusion from given facts.
That you’re carrying an umbrella leads me to deduce that you expect it to rain.

v. 1. To weigh down or burden.
I stumbled through the door, encumbered by my two heavy suitcases.
2. To impede the action of.
Ice floes—large sheets of floating ice—encumbered the ships of early explorers in Antarctica.
n. Encumbrance: Credit card debt was an encumbrance to the young couple as they struggled to save money for their first house.

adj. Full of or accompanied by (usually followed by with).
We abandoned our idea of traveling up the Amazon River when we learned that such a trip would be fraught with danger.

adj. Marked by lack of plan, order, or direction.
He described in humorous detail his haphazard travels around Europe.

adj. Impossible to dispute; unquestionable.
His statement that carbon-dioxide levels in the atmosphere are increasing is incontrovertible.

adj. Hard to explain or impossible to understand.
The disappearance of many ships and planes within the Atlantic Ocean’s Bermuda Triangle is inexplicable to me.

adj. Marked by imagination, resourcefulness, or cleverness.
Disposing of garbage by converting it into energy is an ingenious idea.
n. Ingenuity: When she brought in her science project, the child’s ingenuity was immediately apparent to her teachers.

n. One who falls behind others because of moving slowly or loitering; a straggler.
The laggard crossed the finish line long after the winner had broken the tape.
adj. We have been laggard in getting the roof repaired.

n. Something that provides nourishment; food needed to live.
Roots and berries provided sustenance for the sailors when the storm forced them to abandon ship.

adj. 1. Intensely hot and dry.
It was impossible to walk barefoot on the torrid desert sand.
2. Burning with passion.
The old letter was filled with torrid declarations of undying love.

v. To pass over, across, or through.
Route 66, which traverses the United States from Chicago to Los Angeles, is sometimes called “The Mother Road” because in 1932 it opened the West to automobile travel.
Guido traversed the narrow bridge on foot, terrified of falling into the river below.

adj. Appearing to be present in large numbers or in many different places.
Tourists with cameras are ubiquitous in Europe every summer.

n. 1. The highest point; the peak.
Winning the Nobel Prize for literature was the zenith of her career.
2. The point in the sky directly above the observer.
The sun was well past the zenith by the time we started our hike.

A display of toy soldiers caught my eye.

options: He accepted my advice with caution.

options: The reasons he gave are impossible to figure out.

options: I immediately understood that the task required special tools.
I immediately understood that the task required creative thought.

content.question: The job was done in a haphazard manner.

The job was done in a careless manner.

content.question: The facts of the case are incontrovertible.
options: The facts of the case are open to other points of view.
The facts of the case cannot be doubted.

content.question: We offer sustenance to the hungry.
options: We offer food to the hungry.
We offer a place to live to the hungry.

options: The explorer wrote in great detail about the sub-continent of India.
The explorer traveled across the sub-continent of India.

content.question: The company’s fortunes today are at their zenith.
options: The company’s fortunes today have never been better.
The company’s fortunes today have never been worse.

pages.name: 2E: Vocabulary in Context – Survivors in the Sand
pages.subheading: Answer each question with a sentence. If the question does not contain a word from the lesson, use one in your answer. Use each word only once.

content.name: Passage
passage: An extensive family found under almost every rock are some of the most ubiquitous of insects—ants. Two thousand different species inhabit every part of the Earth except the polar regions. None demonstrates the ability to adapt to harsh environments better than the Black Desert Ant of North Africa.

This small ant, an apparently ingenious creature, lives in underground burrows. It emerges only when it goes searching for food, which is its main form of sustenance. The desert it has to traverse can extend for several hundred yards. Because it has no way of knowing where food might be found, the ant follows a haphazard walk with frequent changes of direction. Its task, fraught with danger, is to survive in the torrid North African desert, where temperatures can climb to 60°C when the sun reaches its zenith. In such heat, the ant’s life depends on the speed with which it can accomplish its goal. The Black Desert Ant has lagged behind in few races in its evolutionary history. That’s an achievement considering that its legs are a fraction of an inch long!

Having located a dead insect, the ant must return quickly to its burrow. This is no easy task for the ant, encumbered with a burden which may weigh more than it does. There is no time for the ant to wonder which direction it should go. Nor does it ask! What is remarkable about the black desert ant, and the reason it has aroused the interest of scientists, is its ability to return to its burrow directly following the shortest possible route.

The desert’s surface is quite featureless. So how does the ant know in which direction to go after it captures its prey? By studying the ant’s brain and observing its behavior, entomologists—scientists who study insects—were able to deduce the answer to this question. They concluded that the ant’s brain must store information about every change of direction, as well as the distances traveled.

Scientists found that the eyes of the black desert ant provide its brain with crucial information. Unlike human eyes, which have only a single lens, the eyes of the black desert ant contain an array of eighty lenses. These multiple lenses change the nature of the light passing through them, causing the light to become polarized. Polarized light vibrates in a single plane instead of scattering and vibrating in many planes at once, as is the case with light passing through a human eye. The polarized light is different for each area of the sky, so that every change in the ant’s path alters the pattern of polarized light registered by the ant’s brain. Should the ant turn, say, thirty degrees to the left, the changed pattern is recorded and stored in the ant’s memory. This pattern then shows the ant its location relative to its burrow, thus enabling the ant to return there directly.

Scientists next tackled the seemingly inexplicable mystery of how the ant measures distance. A surprisingly simple experiment yielded the answer. They set up a narrow track along which the ant had to travel from its burrow. After going thirty feet in a single direction, the ant found a dead insect obligingly placed there by the scientists. The ant now wished to retrace its steps and return to its burrow; but instead, the scientists forced it to go back along a parallel track much longer than the first. After going thirty feet, the ant stopped and began searching for its burrow. To the scientists, this provided incontrovertible proof that the ant measures the distance it has traveled by “counting” its footsteps.

Not all ants have to cope with the hostile environment of the North African desert, but each species of ant is amazing in its own way and has developed its own strategy for survival. Considering what they have learned about insects such as ants, it’s no wonder that many zoologists find entomology fascinating.

content.question: What does the black desert ant's diet consist of?
content.answer: It relies on dead insects for sustenance.

content.question: In what significant way does the Black Desert Ant’s eye differ from a human eye?
content.answer: The Black Desert Ant's eye has an array of lenses, unlike the human eye which has only one.

content.question: What exceptions are there to the statement that ants are ubiquitous?
content.answer: They are not found in polar regions

content.question: Why is it unlikely that the black desert ant will be a laggard when it sets out of the burrow during the middle of the day?
content.answer: In order to survivve, the ant must move quickly when the sun is at its zenith because the temperature can reach a deadly 160 degrees.

content.question: How would the desert ant’s life be even more fraught with danger if it lost the use of its eyes?
content.answer: Its eyes provide its brain with the information necessary to determine its position relative to its burrow so it can return there as quickly as possible.

content.question: In what way does the desert ant return to the burrow with far less trial than on its journey outward in search of food?
content.answer: It traverses the desert in a haphazard when searching for food, but it returns directly, following the shortest possible route.

content.question: Why might the ant’s ability to find its way around the desert seem inexplicable to scientists at first?
content.answer: It seemed difficult to explain because the desert has no landmarks or features to guide the ants

content.question: What did scientists deduce from the fact that the eyes of the desert ant have multiple lenses?
content.answer: The concluded that the great number of lenses provide the ant's brain with additional information on its location so that it can keep track of its position at all times.

content.question: What is one detail from the passage that gives incontrovertible proof that desert ants have a built-in guidance system?
content.answer: The ants take in and process information, as shown by their ability to return directly to their burrow, even if it means a change in route from the one they took leaving their burrow.

content.question: According to the passage, what is one danger that Black Desert Ants are likely to encounter when they leave the burrow?
content.answer: The torrid heat is the greatest danger.

content.question: What detail in the passage supports the statement that desert ants can move with alacrity?
content.answer: It says they can run three hundred feet in less than two minutes.

content.question: Why is an ant's food such an encumbrance?
content.answer: The food (a dead insect) can weig more than the ant carrying it.

content.question: Give one example of ingenuity on the part of the scientists in their study of ants.
content.answer: The scientist developed a clever experiment that showed how ants determine their distance from their burrow. They were also clever in figureing out the function of the multiple lenses of an ant's eye.
